Award.AwardTitle: Teaching Pathways Opening Doors to STEM (TPOD STEM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project "Teaching Pathways Opening Doors to STEM (TPOD STEM)" at Montgomery College is a project to build the college's capacity for preparing highly qualified secondary teachers in STEM disciplines. Collaborating with the Montgomery County (Maryland) Public Schools and the major universities to which these community-college students transfer, the departments of mathematics, science, engineering, and education are engaged in a two-year planning process to recruit, prepare, and support students, both undergraduates in the Associate of Arts in Teaching program and career-changing STEM professionals seeking alternative certification. The capacity of the existing secondary school alternative certification program is being expanded. A new middle-school mathematics/science alternative certification program is being designed and approved by the state. A recruiting model for both levels of future teachers is under development, along with support networks (both physical and virtual) to ensure their success, an important feature of this three-campus institution. With the solid grounding in STEM courses provided by the AAT program, students are well positioned to transfer to STEM majors at baccalaureate institutions while continuing their teacher preparation. Mechanisms for their ongoing support as Noyce Scholars are planned. It is expected that this model can be emulated by other community colleges across the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The single primary goal for this grant project was to increase the number and diversity of highly qualified science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) teachers going into the classroom, by designing, developing and supporting coordinated pathways into K-12 mathematics and science teaching careers for current Montgomery College students and the large population of skilled mathematics and science professionals in the community who may desire to enter the teaching field.  

Key results from the grant work included the following:

  • Adapted from the nationally-recognized Learning Assistant (LA) program at the University of Colorado at Boulder, the Montgomery College program has shown great promise in several areas which impact STEM teacher recruitment and development. Students in this program have the chance to "try on teaching" and provide benefit to the students enrolled in the courses they serve as well as learning from their mentor teachers.  Growing from the fall 2013 semester, with 18 students in 10 different courses ranging from developmental mathematics to advanced computer applications, this program during the spring 2015 semester involved 36 students in 15 different courses across all fields of STEM and all three campuses of Montgomery College.  At least two of these LAs have transferred on to four year schools with a focus on becoming STEM teachers, a change from their career goals before their LA experience.  More such students are in the pipeline now. 
  • Faculty mentors for the Learning Assistant program learned to value the importance of recruiting and encouraging future STEM teachers as they mentored their assigned LAs and interacted with students in their classes and during advising sessions. Awareness of STEM teaching as a career option is growing through the exposure received from this program.
  • An advanced learning community connecting physics and chemistry first courses was developed with funding support from this grant.  This learning community, titled "Curie-us Interactions,"  was planned to provide a follow-up course pair for students who enroll in first semester calculus and are considering a variety of STEM focused careers, including teacher education.  Teachers, students, LAs and course activities were utilized to emphasize the pedagogy involved in science education as well as the course content. 
  • The STEM-Education Community Club provided the opportunity for students to be an active part of the community surrounding Montgomery College by volunteering at a variety of science and mathematics outreach events and camps, such as Frontiers in Science and Medicine and Adventures in Science. The work of this organization supported the research showing that participating in activities which "make a difference" can encourage entry into teaching careers. 
  • Montgomery College, in partnership with Montgomery County Public Schools, offers a Maryland Approved Alternative Preparation Program with a focus on recruiting and preparing teachers in high need areas such as STEM.  As a result of this grant, the program now includes two new areas, middle school mathematics and middle school science, with particular focus on teaching grades four to nine: the first cohort to include this certification area will have their own classrooms for the first year in 2015-16, and assessment of the student impact will be ongoing.
